(1 comment)

Based on you working on this, i'm assuming you would prefer this patch over https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/70850

?

Or are you thinking we should do both?
Not necessarily. I just wanted to get this done and see what it looked like. I don't think both are needed. 70850 might be better - I will leave some more comments on it.

ACK.  Let me know what you think we should do.  I'm pretty open to whatever direction, because I've merged commits that have broken/fixed this feature 3-4 times now.  Clearly my brain isn't comprehending this, so the more the merrier.

@Jonathan, @Ed,

70850 has been WIP to make Request as shared_ptr, and this 71006 seems fulfilling it.
So, I'm good for this approach.

I think one additional test may need to be done by checking the content of `req` inside `completeRequest()` on PATCH approach as 70850 is showing and proving the issue.  (This part won't be seen by default).

> @Jonathan, @Ed,
> 
> 70850 has been WIP to make Request as shared_ptr, and this 71006 seems fulfilling it.
> So, I'm good for this approach.
> 
> I think one additional test may need to be done by checking the content of `req` inside `completeRequest()` on PATCH approach as 70850 is showing and proving the issue.  (This part won't be seen by default).

I think we get that by testing that the HTML json parser works, right?

> I think one additional test may need to be done by checking the content of req inside completeRequest() on PATCH approach as 70850 is showing and proving the issue. (This part won't be seen by default).

I'm not sure what you mean by this. An additional unit test? Or a change in the code is needed?

I think what Ed's getting at (and I agree) is that testing that /redfish/v1 is served as pretty-printed HTML proves that the `req` is still alive in `completeRequest()`.

Please clarify if you mean something else.
No response from Myung.

Comparing with https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/70850, 
the other patch saves the "Accept" field but in case we need other data from the `req`, it will request additional changes.

I prefer this change that makes sure the `req` object is held by the connection and thus fixes the dangling reference issue, and it makes sure the `connection` could use `req` without pre-saving any data.
What does this mean?

It's referring to Redfish URLs (e.g. `/redfish/v1`) being served as pretty-printed HTML JSON instead of raw JSON. It's the expected behavior when the client sends the header `Accept: text/html` and was broken due to a use-after-move bug fixed by this change.
No response from Lei.  Moving forward.

I'm not sure whether it is sufficient without changing `*Rule` (e.g. BaseRule, etc).  Or would it be good without the change?

BaseRule:

```
virtual void handle(const Request& /*req*/,
-->
virtual void handle(const std::shared_ptr<Request>& /*req*/,
```

How about `sserule.hpp` and `websocketrule.hpp` to change?

```
    void handleUpgrade(const Request& req,
```
I think it's ok without changing baserule.  Baserule doesn't do any async operation  that require the Request, so I think we should be ok there.

Agreed with Ed that no rule handlers do any async operations that require ownership. It should simply be a matter of safe coding practice that no references are captured/held across async operations, and I checked all the handlers and did not find any violations of that rule with regard to `Request`.
Done

Jonathan, in terms of this patch, and https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/70850

What are you thinking we should do?  This patch, the other patch, both?  I think both solve the problem, and I don't have a strong opinion either way.

I prefer this one since I think it's ready to go and that other one is not.

The other one (storing necessary headers separately) is fine, but I think it's incomplete since it leaves the Request in a moved-out-of state, and therefore leaves the door cracked for a similar bug to arise. If you added something else to track the validity (e.g. put the Request back in an optional), such that use of a move-out-of Request would crash then I think it'd be more complete.
I am good with this direction.
ACK, we can go with this patch.  Can you add something to the effect of your last comment to 70850 so I can track it?
include memory
Done
